name: hydrazinecarbothioamide, n-phenyl-
Reason: The target compound is an N-phenylhydrazinecarbothioamide. The basic structure can be thought of as derived from thiourea (H2N-CS-NH2), which has a melting point of approximately 182 degrees Celsius due to its ability to form a network of hydrogen bonds and its resonance stabilized planar structure. However, the target compound will have a slightly lower melting point due to the following reasons: 1. Phenyl group (C6H5-): -10 to -20, as it may disrupt hydrogen bonding due to its bulky nature and reduces the number of possible hydrogen bonds as one of the hydrogen bond acceptors (–NH2) is replaced with a phenyl ring. 2. Hydrazino group (–NH–NH2): +0 to +10, as it is similar in hydrogen bonding capability to an amino group but might have some steric hindrance. Overall, we predict a net decrease in melting point compared to thiourea because of the phenyl group's presence.

name: hydrazinecarbothioamide, n-phenyl-

Starting from the melting point of thiourea which is approximately 182 degrees Celsius, the following functional group contributions can be considered: 1. Hydrazino group (–NH–NH2): Similar to an amino group in terms of hydrogen bonding, so its effect on the melting point would be minor.
